title-group.article-title: The Association Between Body Metrics and Breakfast Food Choice in Children

article-meta.aff: Kellogg Company, WK Kellogg Institute for Food and Nutrition, Battle Creek, Michigan (KBM, DJL)
Nutrition Impact, LLC, North Battle Creek, Michigan (VLF)

author-notes.corresp: Kevin B. Miller, PhD, Kellogg Company, WK Kellogg Institute for Food and Nutrition, Battle Creek, MI 49017; e-mail: kevin.miller@kellogg.com.

abstract.p: Purpose. Ready-to-eat cereal (RTEC) consumption has been associated with better nutrient intakes and anthropometric end points compared with breakfast skipping and other breakfasts. Our objective was to evaluate RTEC breakfast type (presweetened and nonpresweetened) on physiological end points. Methods. National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 2003-2006 data were analyzed using SUDAAN. Participants (n = 6729; 2-17 years) were separated into groups based on breakfast habits as follows: presweetened RTEC (PS-RTEC); nonpresweetened RTEC (NPS-RTEC); breakfast skippers (SKs); other breakfasts (OBs). Presweetened was defined as ≥9 g of added sugars per serving. Results. No differences were found for weight, BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure, or lipids in children consuming PS-RTECs or NPS-RTECs. In children 12 to 17 years old, BMI and percentage of children overweight or obese were lower for consumers of PS-RTECs at breakfast compared with SK or OB groups. Skinfolds were significantly lower in PS-RTEC versus SK or OB groups. SK and OB children (12-17 years old) were nearly twice as likely to be overweight or obese as compared with children consuming PS-RTECs (odds ratio of 1.87 and 2.12, respectively). Conclusion. Consumption of breakfast cereal with higher or lower added sugar was not associated with unhealthy physiological end points in children. The study confirms the association between RTEC consumption and healthier body weights compared with children and adolescents skipping or consuming a non-RTEC breakfast.

disp-quote.p: “With the increasing incidence of obesity in American youth, it is necessary to identify the factors that play a role in developing and potentially promoting healthy nutrition habits.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A significant body of literature has shown that ready-to-eat-cereal (RTEC) consumption is associated with a reduced incidence of obesity in children and adults versus breakfast skippers (SKs) or those who eat other breakfasts (OBs).1-4 Several recent publications have also described a positive association between overall nutrient intakes and RTEC consumption in children and adults when compared with SK or OB eating patterns.4-8 The 2010 Dietary Guidelines for Americans (DGA 2010)9 recommends people “eat a nutrient-dense breakfast.” The DGA 2010 further indicates that consuming breakfast has been associated with “weight loss and weight loss maintenance, as well as improved nutrient intake.” As described in the DGA 2005,10 added sugar in presweetened RTECs (PS-RTECs) allows for a food to be palatable. As a result, RTEC is widely accepted by both children and adults. However, the debate on added sugars may affect the decision to provide RTECs to children as well as provide alternate options such as skipping breakfast or eating a less healthy breakfast. With the increasing incidence of obesity in American youth, it is necessary to identify the factors that play a role in developing and potentially promoting healthy nutrition habits. Policy makers give input on dietary guidance, especially in regard to school breakfast and school lunch menu programs, but the evidence base on breakfast habits, outside of greater micronutrient intakes, is relatively small.

Currently, there is no recommendation regarding added sugar intakes for children. The Institute of Medicine states that no more than 25% of total calories should come from added sugars. It was recently reported that children averaged 17% of total energy from added sugars in their diet.11 The National Cancer Institute’s analysis in 2010 of the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data (2005-2006) reported that RTECs contribute only 3.8% of total added sugars to the American diet.12

Published evidence indicates that children who consume either PS-RTECs or nonpresweetened RTEC (NPS-RTEC) have improved body measures as compared with children who consumed OBs, which includes all breakfasts except RTECs.13 Recent observational studies by both O’Neil et al11 and Albertson et al4 found no relationship between added sugars in RTECs and obesity in children and adolescents. In fact, children consuming PS-RTECs were at no greater risk for being overweight or obese than consumers of NPS-RTECs or OBs. The focus of this research was to examine health-related biomarkers and end points associated with the risk of disease, including obesity, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic syndrome.

The objective of this research was to examine the association between breakfast choice and children’s physiological status by answering the question, “Are consumers of PS-RTECs at an increased risk of compromised health status as compared with children who consume NPS-RTECs, OBs, or even SKs?” To evaluate the association between RTEC (PS-RTEC and NPS-RTEC) and OB eating patterns (SK and OB), the anthropometric and physiological data from these 4 breakfast groups were analyzed.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: Data from children and adolescents 2 to 17 years of age (n = 6729) participating in the NHANES 2003-2004 and 2005-2006 were combined for these analyses to increase sample size. Groups excluded from the analyses were women who were pregnant and/or lactating and those with 24-hour recall data judged to be incomplete or unreliable by the USDA’s Food Surveys Research Group. This retrospective observational study was exempt from institutional review board approval.

sec.title: Study Design and Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Regression/logistic regression analyses were conducted in SUDAAN using appropriate sample weights to adjust for complex sample design of the NHANES, 2003-2006. Participants were separated into groups based on breakfast habits: PS-RTECs (n = 1594), NPS-RTECs (n = 578), SKs (n = 1260), and OBs/non-RTECs (n = 3297). Subsets of the population were also analyzed and included young children (2-5 years old), older children (6-11 years old), and adolescents (12-17 years old).

The modeling procedure PROC REGRESS of SUDAAN was used to estimate sample-weighted least-square means and standard errors. The odds ratio and 95% confidence interval of the odds ratio were estimated using the PROC LOGISTIC function of SUDAAN.

Two models were evaluated that included adjustment for the following: model 1, which included energy (kcal), gender, age (years), and ethnicity, and model 2, which included the same characteristics as model 1 plus poverty income ratio, physical activity, and TV/computer use. Because results were similar for the 2 models, only data from the second model that included poverty income ratio, physical activity, and TV/computer use will be presented, except where noted (Table 1). A P value of less than .05 was deemed significant.

caption.p: Prevalence of Risk Factors for Overweight, Abdominal Obesity, Hypertension, and Low HDL Cholesterol by Breakfast Consumption Habits in Children Aged 12 to 17 Years Olda

fn.p: Abbreviations: RTEC, ready-to-eat cereal; HDL, high-density lipoprotein.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Covariates: energy (kcal), gender, age (year), ethnicity, poverty income ratio (PIR), physical activity, TV/computer use, and smoking.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Covariates: energy (kcal), BMI (kg/m2), gender, age (years), ethnicity, PIR, physical activity, TV/computer use, smoking.

fn.label: d,e,f
fn.p: Means with different superscripts among these differ by P < .05.

sec.p: Blood pressure was only collected in children 8 years and older14; therefore, data are presented for adolescents (12-17 years). Serum lipid levels are collected and reported in the NHANES for children 5 years and older starting in 2005. Data for each of the breakfast patterns on total and HDL cholesterol were analyzed in older children (6-11 years old) and adolescents (12-17 years old). Data on fasting total cholesterol (TC), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and triglycerides (TGs) were also analyzed in older children and adolescents.

sec.title: Physiological Measures
sec.p: Height and weight, blood pressure,14 waist circumference,15 and laboratory values of serum lipids16 were obtained according to NHANES protocols. BMI was calculated as body weight (in kilograms) divided by height (in meters) squared. The percentile BMI for age was calculated using growth charts available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

sec.title: Definitions
sec.p: PS-RTEC was defined as cereal with added sugars equal to or more than 9 g per serving of RTEC. The amount of 9 g was selected because it represents less than the median of added sugars in breakfast cereals and “single-digit” is an amount consumers can recognize. Added-sugar values were obtained from the MyPyramid Equivalents Database.17 The Centers for Disease Control growth chart program (CDC 2000) was used to determine BMI percentiles and percentage of the population overweight/obese (BMI percentile ≥85/BMI percentile ≥95). Abdominal obesity (ie, waist circumference) was assessed using the child’s waist circumference measurements in relation to a reference population. High LDL-C was defined as a level ≥100 mg/dL. Metabolic syndrome was defined as the presence of 3 or more risk factors, including abdominal obesity and waist circumference ≥90th percentile for age and gender group.18 Hypertension was defined as blood pressure ≥90th percentile based on 2004 NIH Heart, Lung, Blood Institute/National High Blood Pressure Education Program (NHBPEP). Also, guidelines include low HDL-C (≤40 mg/dL), high TGs (≥110 mg/dL), and high fasting glucose (≥100 mg/dL) as further risk factors for metabolic syndrome.

sec.title: Breakfast Eating Habits
sec.p: Children were categorized into 1 of 4 breakfast eating patterns that included PS-RTEC, NPS-RTEC, OBs, and SKs. Comparison of breakfast eating patterns indicated that only 5% of children 2 to 5 years old skipped breakfast, as compared with 14% and 28% of 6- to 11-year-old and 12- to 17-year-old children, respectively. Consumption of OBs (non-RTEC breakfast) remained somewhat consistent at approximately 50% of all children surveyed between the ages of 2 and 17 years. The percentage of children consuming either PS-RTECs or NPS-RTECs declined with increasing age, indicating no difference in preference for RTEC type with age.

sec.title: Young children
sec.p: The only significant differences among groups were the percentage of children classified as overweight and obese between the PS-RTEC and SK groups (P < .05). No other differences were observed among the breakfast consumer groups for anthropometric end points in young children (Table 2).

caption.p: Covariate-Adjusted Mean Weight, Body Mass Index (BMI), Percentile of BMI for Age, Prevalence of Overweight/Obesity, Waist Circumference, and Skinfold Thickness by Consumption of Presweetened Ready-to-Eat Cereal at Breakfasta

fn.p: Abbreviations: RTEC, ready-to-eat cereal; NS, not significant.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are mean (standard error); covariates for analyses included energy (kcal), gender, age (years), and ethnicity (model 1); and model 2, the same as model 1 plus poverty income ratio, physical activity, and TV/computer use.

fn.label: b,c,d
fn.p: Means with different superscripts among these differ by P < .05.

sec.title: Older children
sec.p: BMI was greater in the SK group of children when compared with the OB group, but the SK group was not different from either RTEC group. The BMI percentile, percentage of children classified as overweight or obese, increased waist circumference, and elevated subscapular skin fold thickness were significantly greater in SK and OB than in the PS-RTEC group (P < .01).

sec.title: Adolescents
sec.p: The most notable differences among groups were found in adolescents. Body weight, BMI, BMI percentile, percentage overweight/obese, and waist circumference were all lower in the PS-RTEC group as compared with the SK and OB groups (P < .05). Subscapular and triceps skinfolds were also lower in the PS-RTEC group compared with the SK and OB groups (P < .05). There were no differences found between the 2 RTEC groups (PS-RTEC or NPS-RTEC) for any of the anthropometric measurements in adolescents.

sec.title: Older children
sec.p: In the nonfasting serum samples, no differences in total cholesterol were found among any of the breakfast groups, but children who ate RTEC (PS-RTEC or NPS-RTEC) had significantly lower HDL-C levels than those who skipped breakfast (SK) or ate OBs (Table 3; P < .05). No differences in TC were seen in fasting samples from older children. However, LDL-C concentrations were lower in the PS-RTEC than in the OB group but not different from that in the SK or NPS-RTEC groups. Older children who ate NPS-RTECs had lower HDL-C and higher TGs, but only in comparison with the PS-RTEC group.

caption.p: Covariate-Adjusted Mean Serum Lipid Level by Consumption of Presweetened (>9 g/serving Added Sugar) Ready-to-Eat Cereal at Breakfasta

fn.p: Abbreviations: RTEC, ready-to-eat cereal; NS, not significant; HDL, high-density lipoprotein; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; SBP, systolic blood pressure; DBP, diastolic blood pressure.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are mean (standard error); covariates included: energy (kcal), BMI (kg/m2), gender, age (years), ethnicity, poverty income ratio, physical activity, and TV/computer use.

fn.label: b,c
fn.p: Means with different superscripts among these differ by P < .05.

sec.title: Adolescents
sec.p: In nonfasting serum samples from adolescents, TC was lower in the NPS-RTEC group compared with the SK and OB groups but not different from the PS-RTEC group. HDL-C was lower in PS-RTEC consumers but only compared to the OB group. In the fasting serum of adolescents, TC was lower in both PS-RTEC and NPS-RTEC consumers compared with the SK group but not different from the OB group. PS-RTEC consumers also had lower LDL-C as compared with the SK group but the values were not different from those for the NSP-RTEC or OB groups. No differences in fasting serum samples for HDL-C or TGs were observed among the various groups of adolescents.

sec.title: Blood Pressure
sec.p: In fasting adolescents, blood pressure (systolic and diastolic) was not different among the 4 groups. In nonfasting adolescents, there was a significant difference in systolic blood pressure between the NPS-RTEC and OB groups (Table 3; P < .05). A trend was also observed between the 2 RTEC groups, where the systolic pressure of the NPS-RTEC group tended to be lower than that of the PS-RTEC group, but this did not reach significance (P = .06).

sec.title: Adolescents
sec.p: The prevalence of risk factors, including hypertension, abdominal obesity, overweight or obese, and low HDL-C concentrations, were assessed by breakfast category in adolescents. The risk of both abdominal obesity (>95th percentile for weight) and being overweight (>85th percentile for weight) were greater in both SK and OB groups as compared with the PS-RTEC group (P < .01; Table 1). Conversely, both SK and OB consumers were at lower risk of low HDL-C concentrations as compared with PS-RTEC consumers (P < .05). There were no differences between PS-RTEC and NPS-RTEC groups in the prevalence for risk of overweight, abdominal obesity, hypertension, or low HDL-C in adolescents.

sec.title: Odds of Being Overweight or Obese
Young children
sec.p: The odds of being overweight or obese in young children was found to be significantly greater (2.03 times as likely to be overweight or obese) in the SK group as compared with the PS-RTEC group (Table 4).

caption.p: OR (95% CI) for Overweight/Obesity by Consumption of Presweetened (>9 g/serving Added Sugar) RTEC at Breakfasta

fn.p: Abbreviations: RTEC, ready-to-eat cereal; OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are odds ratio (95% confidence interval); covariates: energy (kcal), gender, age (years), ethnicity, poverty income ratio, physical activity, TV/computer use, and smoking.

sec.title: Older children
sec.p: There were no significant differences in the risk for obesity among the 4 groups of older children.

sec.title: Adolescents
sec.p: In adolescents, a similar effect to the young children was found, where the SK group was 1.87 times more likely to be overweight or obese as compared with the PS-RTEC group. The data also show that adolescents who consumed OBs were 2.12 times more likely to be overweight or obese when compared with PS-RTEC consumers. However, no differences were found between the 2 RTEC breakfast groups (PS-RTEC and NPS-RTEC).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Ready-to-eat breakfast cereals are a popular choice with children, and PS-RTEC is often favored because of the taste. However, little is known about the impact of these foods on health outcomes. Prior research on added sugar and RTECs has focused on micronutrient intakes and body weight4,11 but did not provide insight beyond basic anthropometrics into how these food choices may affect health outcomes. Although the sugar content of PS-RTECs has been implicated in contributing to and promoting obesity, the data presented here do not support that conclusion.

Categorizing breakfast food consumption into 4 separate groups, including both PS-RTECs and NPS-RTECs, OBs, and SKs, allowed for a better examination of breakfast habits and children’s health than that seen in previous research. However, it is important to note that the anthropometric data presented here align with the previous research.4,11 Consumption of RTECs (presweetened or not) was not associated with increased body weight. In fact, across the 4 breakfast categories, it was shown that body weight was highest in the those children who skip breakfast and lowest in the PS-RTEC group. This observation of higher body weight in the SK group and lower body weight in the PS-RTEC group was found in each of the 3 age groups assessed. These data confirm that breakfast skipping is an unhealthy behavior regardless of a child’s age.

The data presented in this article and in previous studies all share the finding that breakfast consumption is associated with a lower incidence of overweight and obesity. This study builds on the published research and examined physiological end points associated with health, including serum lipids and blood pressure in children and adolescents.

Long-term health is the primary goal in promoting healthy nutrition behavior in children. The blood lipid data, in combination with the anthropometric data, may be useful in assessing future health in children, as suggested previously.19,20 Few differences in blood lipids were noted among the 4 categories of breakfast behaviors. Despite statistical differences reported in HDL-C between the children consuming RTECs and those who did not consume RTECs (or breakfast), children in all 4 groups were within the desirable range for HDL-C (>45 mg/dL). In both the older children and adolescents, there were several statistical differences among the groups, but values for TC, LDL-C, HDL-C, and TG were still within desirable ranges. It has previously been reported that TG concentrations in children are related to their consumption of sugars.21 However, no relationship was found between the PS-RTEC eaters and TG concentrations in either the 6- to 11- or 12- to 17-year-old subgroups. In fact, our data showed that samples from fasting children, 6 to 11 years old, who consumed PS-RTECs had significantly lower concentrations of TGs than samples from children consuming NPS-RTECs.

The consumption of breakfast improves overall daily micronutrient intakes as compared with skipping breakfast.22 Consumption of breakfast has also been associated with multiple benefits in children, including scholastic performance—potentially through either a nutritive effect or improved attendance.23 The benefits of regular breakfast consumption are not limited to the short term. Breakfast consumption during childhood and adulthood has been correlated with long-term cardiovascular health.24 As a result of these findings, there is substantial evidence to support the public (USDA Food & Nutrition Service) and private sectors’ initiatives to provide breakfast to children. In addition, these data may be useful in identifying healthy eating patterns for implementation of nutritional strategies to maintain healthy weight in children and adolescents.

Despite all these health benefits, there is a disturbing trend for children to reduce their frequency of breakfast consumption as they mature into adolescents, especially in the later teen years. Our findings regarding reduced breakfast consumption with age is in agreement with other published literature that showed that breakfast consumption declines as children age.25,26 The observation that RTEC consumption at breakfast decreased while OB consumption remained relatively constant was not surprising. This may be because OB is classified as all foods (excluding RTEC) and includes, but is not limited to, waffles, breakfast sandwiches, toast, milk, and juice but also other caloric foods including soda, snacks, and candy. The OB category is therefore not limited to wholesome foods and likely represents an increasing proportion of foods with low nutrient density.

Although the data supporting the benefits of consuming breakfast are accepted, there is continued debate about the role of different breakfast patterns in health,27 and although previous research on the benefits of breakfast has included RTECs as one breakfast pattern, the role of PS-RTECs in a healthy breakfast has raised controversy. For example, some researchers have suggested that PS-RTECs may contribute to childhood obesity because of the added sugar content.28 Research addressing a potential link between added sugars and obesity is equivocal and dependent on food source (eg, beverage vs solid foods), and therefore, the influence of added sugars on obesity is poorly understood.29 Concerns also have been raised that added sugars may dilute the nutrient content of a child’s diet.30,31 However, a review on added sugars and the diet indicate that these data are inconsistent, and therefore, it is difficult to draw meaningful conclusions.32-34 In addition, studies on nutrient intakes have shown that RTEC consumers have superior intakes of nearly all micronutrients.22 The DGA (2005)10 stated that “small amounts of sugars added to nutrient-dense foods, such as breakfast cereals and reduced fat milk products, may increase a person’s intake of such foods by enhancing the palatability of these products, thus improving nutrient intake without contributing excessive calories.”

A major finding of interest in this study is that consumption of PS-RTECs was not associated with a higher incidence of obesity in children. Because PS-RTECs have a greater amount of added sugars per serving than NPS-RTECs, there has been speculation that PS-RTECs may negatively affect weight and contribute to a higher prevalence of obesity. Sweetened breakfast cereals have been criticized because it is believed that they also contribute more calories by either decreasing nutrient density or increasing consumption beyond serving size.26 However, the published literature indicates that total calories consumed by adolescents who eat PS-RTECs are not different from those eating NPS-RTECs.11 Our data show that no association exists between the type of breakfast cereal and anthropometric or physiological measures in children. Most noteworthy was that children consuming PS-RTECs typically ranked the lowest of the 4 groups in many of the end points evaluated. Reasons for this observation are unclear and deserve further investigation.

In conclusion, these data show no differences in terms of physiological measures or risk factors for health between children who consume PS-RTECs and NPS-RTECs. These data also confirm that PS-RTECs or NPS-RTECs are associated with lower body weights, reduced obesity, and smaller waist circumference as compared with SKs or even consumers of other food at breakfast. These results indicate that breakfast cereal, at either sugar content level, can be a healthy choice, which is important in promoting good nutrition behavior in children, especially during their teenage years when healthy breakfast habits become less consistent.

ack.p: The authors thank Debra R. Keast, PhD, for providing NHANES database analyses support for the project.
